oai_dc:dc.dc:title: State Street Aqueduct, Fort Plain, New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard view of the State Street Aqueduct that carried canal traffic over the Otsquago Creek in Fort Plain, New York. This aqueduct was located west of present day Haslett Park and west of the present day Fort Plain Free Library's River Street entrance. The aqueduct was destroyed by flooding of the Otsquago Creek in the early 1980's.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort Plain Free Library
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Harvey E. Williams opened the first tin and hardware store in the village of Fort Plain, New York in 1827. His home (shown in the picture) was located in close proximity to the Erie Canal and lift bridge (left rear of picture) and was given by his descendents to the Fort Plain Free Library Association in 1909 as a permanent location for the library that had been chartered by the State of New York in 1894.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Kitty (Kittie) West
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Kitty (Kittie) West was an excursion boat built in 1882. The boat was 87 feet long and could hold 134 passengers. The boat was sold in 1912 and was then used to transport produce along the Erie Canal.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: View of Fort Plain from Prospect Hill 1879
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: View of Fort Plain, the Erie Canal, and the Mohawk River mid 1800's. Pictured are bridges spanning the Erie Canal from present day Canal and State Streets. Canal boats are show navigating the canal. To the far left of the picture, a covered bridge spans the Mohawk River connecting Fort Plain to Nelliston, NY.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fineour's Canal Store
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A photograph of Fred Fineour's canal store taken circa 1890. Fred Fineour's store dealt in groceries, provisions, hay, oats, straw, hardwood, bow and tie lines for both canalers and local residents. The store was located on present day State Street in Fort Plain, NY. Pictured in the photograph are Fred Fineour (leaning against post), Minnie Fineour (daughter of Fred Fineour standing to his right), Kitty VanSlyke Fineour (wife of Fred Fineour standing to Minnie's right). little boy unkown and woman with hat unknown. The building was disassembled and is currently at the New York State Museum. A replica built to scale of the Fineour Store is on permanent display at the Fort Plain Museum. This picture is a slide of the original photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph showing winter maintenance of the Erie Canal in Fort Plain, New York. The view of the canal looks west behind the buildings which now line present day Canal Street.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Enlarging the Erie Canal in Fort Plain, New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of workers enlarging the Erie Canal along Hancock Street in Fort Plain, New York. Enlarging the canal took place between the years 1836 and 1862. The width of the canal was increased from 40 feet to 70 feet. The depth increased from 4 feet to 7 feet.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The armory at Clinton Liberal Institute
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The armory at the Clinton Liberal Institute was built in 1891. At the time it was one of the largest armories in the country. The armory was adjoined to the cadets' gymnasium and the drill floor measured 150x82 feet. The main purpose of the armory was for military drill but it also served all indoor athletic sports, in addition to dances and sociable gatherings. The armory was connected to the main building by a covered passageway.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cadets on front lawn of Clinton Liberal Institute
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of the Clinton Liberal Institute Battalion of Cadets taken in front of the school in 1892. The group of officers standing from left to right are Cadet 1st Lieutenant Willard Chamberlain of Freehold, NJ, Professor Birney E. Trask, teacher of mathematics, Cadet Captain Frank H. Fayant, Fort Plain, NY, Professor James Warbasse, teacher of bookkeeping, Captain E. J. Stivers, U.S.A, retired, Commandant of Cadets, Professor Tracy E. Clark, teacher of science, Cadet Captain Carlton A. Perry, Fort Plain, NY, and Cadet 1st Lieutenant C. Ralph Corbin, Binghamton, NY. Sitting left to right are Cadet 2nd Lieutenant Fred Eaton, Little Falls, NY, Cadet 2nd Lieutenant Clifford Crowell, Catskill, NY, Cadet 2nd Lieutenant Fred Link, Erie, PA, Cadet Sargeant Major Gilbert Holmes, Redwood, NY, Cadet 2nd Lieutenant Murray Hines, North Adams, MA. Standing on the porch 3rd from the right is Professor Charles V. Parsell( heavy bearded), President of the Institute from 1879 to 1893.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Drawing of Fort Plain with the Clinton Liberal Institute in the background
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The drawing shows the village of Fort Plain, New York from the Nelliston side of the Mohawk River. In the background of the drawing sits the Fort Plain Seminary and Collegiate Institute on what was once called "Seminary Hill." The school fell upon hard times during the 1870's and had decided to close in 1878 when it was taken over by the Clinton Liberal Institute which moved to Fort Plain from Clinton, New York, in 1879.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clinton Liberal Institute Cadets at target practice
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Clinton Liberal Institute cadets are shown in front of the armory engaged in battle formation with infantry fire. A course in the instruction and practice of rifle firing was given at the Institute. The Ordinance Department of the United States Army furnished the Institute with arms and equipment for Infantry, Artillery, and Signal Corps, as well as with all the necessary ammunition. An officer of the U.S. Army was in charge of the Military Department within the Institute. Cadets were offered a preparatory course for entrance into West Point and Annapolis.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: View of the Clinton Liberal Institute from present day West Street
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Clinton Liberal Institute comprised nine and one-half acres. There were four buildings on site. The main building (shown) was six stories high and contained classrooms, a chapel, the library, reception rooms, an auditorium, student rooms, and a dining room. The other three buildings were the ladies' gymnasium, the mens' gymnasium, and the armory.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clinton Liberal Institute destroyed by fire March, 1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On March 25, 1900 the Clinton Liberal Institute burned to the ground. While the students and faculty were away at spring break, a fire broke out while the building was being fumigated as a result of a scarlet fever epidemic. The loss was estimated at $100,000. It was hoped that the Universalist Society would take over the rebuilding of the school but that did not happen. The seminary, however, was moved to St. Lawrence University in Canton, New York.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Remains of the burned out Clinton Liberal Institute
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: What is left of the Clinton Liberal Institute following the fire on March 25, 1900 is shown in this photograph. The building made of wood and brick was quickly engulfed in flames. Although outfitted with sprinkler systems the low water pressure made it impossible to contain the fire.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clinton Liberal Institute female cadets at drill practice
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1892, female students at the CLI began to take regular military drill as depicted in the photograph. They drilled twice a week for one hour at a time. The school adopted this program as a result of their belief that this form of exercise was as beneficial to young ladies as it was to men. The ladies wore a special uniform consisting of a dark blue blazer and skirt, a white vest, and a cap.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clinton Liberal Institute Mathematics room
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In the room pictured in the photograph the following courses were taught at the Clinton Liberal Institute: Academic Algebra, Higher Algebra, Plane Geometry, Solid Geometry, Plane and Spherical Trigonometry, Conic Sections and Surveying. Pictured are dictation settees used by the students, teacher's desk, and instruments used in the surveying course.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clinton Liberal Institute students at fencing practice
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cadets practicing fencing in the armory of the CLI. Equipment for fencing (masks, jackets, and foils) along with equipment for other sports such as boxing was stored in the armory. In the background of this photograph one can see the musical instruments stored for the cadet band. Also shown are the flags of the nations hanging from the rafters.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clinton Liberal Institute auditorium/chapel
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Clinton Liberal Institute was owned by the Universalist Society of New York. Students enrolled at the school were required to attend chapel services. Shown is the CLI chapel along with a portion of the chapel stage. The chapel was located on both the fourth and fifth floors of the CLI building.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Art Class at the Clinton Liberal Institute
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pictured is one of four rooms which comprised the art studio suite at the CLI. Full time students in the School of Art were entitled to three hours practice in the studio a day while part-time students were allowed three hours two days a week. Art courses in sketching, painting, and art history were offered.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clinton Liberal Institute gymnasium
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A photograph of the gentlemen's gymnasium is shown here. The gentlemen's gymnasium was 70 feet long and 35 feet wide and two stories high. The second story is depicted showing some of the gymnastic equipment: ropes, ladders, and parallel bars. The first story (not shown) contained 4 bowling alleys, trapezes, and vaulting standards. All boarding cadets had to pay a gymnasium fee of $3.00 each and a tax of $.75 each session. Day students were excused from paying the fee if they chose not to pay but then were not allowed use of the gymnasium or armory except for drill and ceremonies.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clinton Liberal Institute science room
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This photograph shows the general science recitation room. The room had 60 feet of cases which stored the school's museum collection in conchology, geology, botany, and biology. In addition to this room, there were three other science rooms comprising 1,571 square feet altogether. In the background of the photo a professor and his students can be seen.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clinton Liberal Institute kitchen
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ladies are shown in this photograph preparing one of the three meals a day provided to those students boarding at the CLI.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clinton Liberal Institute dining room
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The main section of the dining room was 72 feet long by 28 feet wide. A room of 24 feet long and 19 feet wide opened into it. Table room was provided for about 200 students and teachers. Teachers were in charge of each table. A Cadet officer served as carver and also was responsible for the conduct of those at the table when the teacher was not present.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clinton Liberal Institute lecture hall/classroom
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: As described in the 1893 Clinton Liberal Institute catalog classrooms were supplied with" the best of modern desks" as pictured here in what was considered a lecture hall.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clinton Liberal Institute Library
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The library of the CLI in 1898 boasted 4000 volumes of which 1200 were reference books. A librarian was in attendance to aid in the borrowing and consultation of books. Pictured are female students and male cadets engaged in reading and studying. In addition to the library there were two large reading rooms, one for the ladies and one for the cadets. These rooms were supplied with the popular magazines of the day and the daily and weekly newspapers from New York City, Albany, and Utica, New York.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clinton Liberal Institute boiler room
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pictured are the boilers which provided the heat and hot water to the five story building and the armory Rooms within the CLI were heated by steam and each room in the building contained radiators.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Clinton Liberal Institute
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Clinton Liberal Institute was originally founded in Clinton, New York in 1834 under the patronage of the Universalist Church. In 1878 it was relocated to Fort Plain, New York and was housed in the former Fort Plain Female Seminary and Collegiate Institute built in 1853. It was a boarding school which housed about 200 students both young men and women from all over the world. The school was designed for pupils between the ages of 13 and 24.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Crowd watches as the Clinton Liberal Institute burns
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A photograph of some of the residents of the village of Fort Plain watching the progress of the diasterous fire which destroyed the Clinton Liberal Institute on March 25, 1900.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort Plain Street Fair Acrobats
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photo showing three acrobats performing at the Fort Plain Street Fair. This photo was taken sometime between 1898 and 1924. The acrobats performed on a platform at the corner of Main and Center Streets in the village.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Saltsman, Myron, 1920-2010 (Local Historian); Fort Plain Free Library (Archives); Chambers, Eileen (Village Historian)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational and personal uses. Please cite: Fort Plain Free Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort Plain Street Fair Trapeze Artists
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photo showing trapeze artists performing at the corner of Canal and River Streets in the village of Fort Plain during the annual Street Fair Days which were held for one week during the month of September from 1898 to 1924. In the background is the River Street lift bridge over the Erie Canal.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Saltsman, Myron, 1920-2010 (Local Historian); Fort Plain Free Library (Archives); Chambers, Eileen (Village Historian)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational and personal uses. Please cite: Fort Plain Free Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort Plain Street Fair High Wire Act
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photo showing the high wire act across Main Street during the annual Street Fair Days. This photo was taken in 1922.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Saltsman, Myron, 1920-2010 (Local Historian); Fort Plain Free Library (Archives); Chambers, Eileen (Village Historian)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational and personal uses. Please cite: Fort Plain Free Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort Plain Street Fair High Diver Act
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photo of a high diver 90 feet above a 6ft deep pool of water. This was a very popular attraction at the Fort Plain Street Fair which was held in the village during the month of September to coincide with Constitution Day.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Saltsman, Myron, 1920-2010 (Local Historian); Fort Plain Free Library (Archives); Chambers, Eileen (Village Historian)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational and personal uses. Please cite: Fort Plain Free Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort Plain Street Fair Lion Tamer Act
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photo showing the lion tamer act in front of a large crowd on Canal Street in the village of Fort Plain during the annual Street Fair Days which were held for a week during the month of September. The photo was taken in 1923.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Saltsman, Myron, 1920-2010 (Local Historian); Fort Plain Free Library (Archives); Chambers, Eileen (Village Historian)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational and personal uses. Please cite: Fort Plain Free Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort Plain Street Fair
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color enhanced photo of looking west on Canal Street during the annual Street Fair held in the village of Fort Plain for a week during the month of September. In the foreground is the movable bandstand on which the Old Fort Plain Band performed for the crowds. Also in the photo are the canvas covered booths from which merchants sold their wares. In the background is the town clock, a village landmark.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Saltsman, Myron, 1920-2010 (Local Historian); Fort Plain Free Library (Archives); Chambers, Eileen (Village Historian)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational and personal uses. Please cite: Fort Plain Free Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort Plain Street Fair Marvelous Melville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Marvelous Melville the Supreme Gymnast performed his act on the corner of Main and Center Streets in the village of Fort Plain during the September 1923 annual Street Fair. The act was performed in front of the Fort Plain Hotel, formerly known at the Zoller House. In the background of the picture is Dievendorf Hall which housed the Rialto Theater which offered movies during Street Fair Days.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Saltsman, Myron, 1920-2010 (Local Historian); Fort Plain Free Library (Archives); Chambers, Eileen (Village Historian)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational and personal uses. Please cite: Fort Plain Free Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tractor and Wagon Parade Fort Plain Street Fair
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photo of a tractor and wagon parade which took place during the annual Street Fair Days during the month of September in the village of Fort Plain. The tractors and wagons are lined up on Main Street in front of the Betzinger Factory which manufactured carriages in the late 19th century.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Saltsman, Myron, 1920-2010 (Local Historian); Fort Plain Free Library (Archives); Chambers, Eileen (Village Historian)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational and personal uses. Please cite: Fort Plain Free Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort Plain Street Fair High Diver Act
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photo taken from the roof of the Hotel Fort Plain looking east on Main Street. In the background are the canvas covered booths in which were displayed merchants and farmers goods. A large crowd has gathered to view the high diver act. On the right of the photo two buildings down stands Dievendorf Hall which housed the Rialto Theater which showed moving pictures during Street Fair Week in September.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Saltsman, Myron, 1920-2010 (Local Historian); Fort Plain Free Library (Archives); Chambers, Eileen (Village Historian)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational and personal uses. Please cite: Fort Plain Free Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort Plain Street Fair
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photo of Canal Street during Street Fair Days in September, 1900. A campaign banner is stretched across Canal Street for William McKinley and Theodore Roosevelt who were running on the Republican ticket in the 1900 election. In the foreground is the movable bandstand on which the Old Fort Plain Band ws performing. Also shown in the photo is a canvas covered booth displaying merchants wares and the large crowds that attended the fair.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Old Fort Plain Band
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photo of the Old Fort Plain Band on the steps of the Fritcher Opera House. The band was organized in 1852 and at times numbered up to twenty-five musicians. The band entertained village residents at summer concerts in the park, on the bandstand during street fair days, and parades. The Fritcher Opera House was located on River Street in the village of Fort Plain. The Opera House was built in 1878 and burned in 1911
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Saltsman, Myron, 1920-2010 (Local Historian); Fort Plain Free Library (Archives); Chambers, Eileen (Village Historian)
